bestBHT.bht: Inquiring about the Pharisees and Scribes' belief regarding the Messiah, Jesus sheds light on their view of His lineage. By asking them whose son the Messiah would be and drawing attention to David's acknowledgment of the Messiah as his Lord, Jesus underscores the authenticity and inspiration of the Old Testament scriptures. This encounter presents a remarkable insight into the accuracy of the Evangelists, reinforcing the significance of accurately reporting Jesus' words and illuminating the independence of the Gospel accounts.

Henry Alford: I mention these things as marks of the independence of the accounts.
The underlying fact is, the Lord addressed the Pharisees and Scribes on a view which they (the Scribes, the Pharisees agreeing) entertained about the Messiah.
If His words were so loosely reported as this, where is any dependence on the accuracy of the Evangelists?
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: What think ye of Christ [the promised and expected Messiah]? Whose son is He [to be]?"
How then doth David in spirit [by the Holy Ghost] call Him Lord?"
Mark the testimony here given to the inspiration of the Old Testament.
Archibald T. Robertson: By 'they say' (λεγουσιν) Jesus refers to the Pharisees...turning the tables on them while the Pharisees are still gathered together."
The construction with λεγουσιν is the usual infinitive and the accusative in indirect discourse.
By 'the Christ' (τον Χριστον) 'the Messiah' is meant.

This incident showcases the independence of the Gospel accounts and emphasizes the importance of accurately reporting the words of Jesus.
